This book resonated with me in so many ways, including the seemingly unrelated topics of alcoholism, OCD and PTSD symptoms. I'm absolutely amazed at how far the "five keys" extend. Chapter 3 (key 2) was especially helpful to me in managing unwanted thoughts.

Even though this book is geared towards sexual addiction, the methods presented in it are applicable to a range of other issues. 

This is one of the few books I know of that offers help to both the addict and the family/friends of the addict. The guidelines given are applicable to anyone who wants to help their family member/friend with any kind of issue.

I was also pleasantly surprised to see so much information packed into every page. The book is short. And so it should be. I am sick of sifting through 200-300-page self-help books in which the primary purpose of the author seems to be to hear him/herself talk. I can't tell you how many of those books I didn't finish. "The Language of Recovery" is short, it's to the point and it doesn't mince words. I finished it--and for that reason alone it's worth the price.

For those among us who are atheists, agnostics, or "unforgiven": The book takes a faith-based approach, especially Chapter 6. However, I must stress that the scripture quotes are NOT OVERWHELMING. They are applicable, and they illustrate the points very well. (If you know my views, you will recognize this as a very high compliment!) If you fall into one of the categories I mentioned, Chapter 6 (key 5) may not be for you. Or, it may be exactly what you need. The two points I'm trying to make, without giving too much away, are these: 

1. What you believe becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy. 
2. Believe in your success and you will find it that much easier to work towards it. 

There. There's your atheist definition of "faith" with a lower-case "f". Taking this approach should make Chapter 6 a lot easier to read and to take in.

Conclusion: Great book, written by someone who seems to truly want to help instead of to hear himself talk.
